Award.AwardTitle: Controls on South Pacific Convergence Zone Precipitation and Its Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ), a large region of cloudiness and rainfall south of the equator extending southeastward from the Western Pacific (the warm pool region) past Fiji and American Samoa to about 30S, 140W. The basic dynamics that produce the SPCZ are still poorly understood, and climate models have difficulty in simulating it correctly (the simulated SPCZ is often too zonally oriented and too close to the equator). This project has two objectives: first, to diagnose multiscale SPCZ circulation-moisture-precipitation relationships evident in observations, reanalysis datasets, and simulations of current generation coupled climate models (from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project version 5). Second, to develop an SPCZ region air mass trajectory climatology using a parcel dispersion model. A fully 3-dimensional, Lagrangian perspective of the pathways of air masses interacting with the SPCZ will be produced and analyzed, motivated by the idea that variations in the flow of dry air into the SPCZ drives precipitation variability in the region.

Aside from its scientific merit, the work is expected to produce results of interest to decision makers and stakeholders in the South Pacific, who would benefit from better understanding of rainfall variability given vulnerability to floods and droughts in the region. The Pacific Centre for Environmental and Sustainable Development (PACE-SD) will serve as a venue for interactions between the PI of this project and South Pacific researchers, forecasters, and decision makers. The project also fosters international collaborations, including collaborations with the Australian Bureau of Meteorology and the participation of a Costa Rican scientist with expertise on Lagrangean trajectory analysis. In addition, the project supports and trains a graduate student, thereby providing for the future work force in this research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ) comprises a vast area of intense low-level convergence, convective cloudiness, and precipitation extending from the tropical western Pacific to Southern Hemisphere midlatitudes of the central Pacific.   However, despite being one of the largest and most prominent climatic features on earth, the SPCZ is relatively understudied, with fundamental questions remaining about its genesis and variability.  The principal scientific thrust of this project has been to provide insights into the mechanisms controlling rainfall and its variability in the SPCZ, both as observed and as represented in climate models. 

In two related publications, we examined the interplay of atmospheric circulation, moisture, and rainfall in the SPCZ on synoptic timescales.  Our efforts identified how “upstream” conditions along the Southern Hemisphere storm track influence rainfall along the subtropical portion of the SPCZ (see schematic below).  We have also demonstrated that current generation models (i.e., Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5, or CMIP5, models) are generally successful in capturing the observed characteristics of the relationships among circulation, moisture, and precipitation on synoptic timescales, despite biases in their climatological representation of the SPCZ.  On-going analysis of observed daily rainfall in the SPCZ region is making use of tools, e.g., k-means clustering with linear unidimensional scaling and self-organizing maps, which have not been widely used in climate science, to generate additional insights into controls on SPCZ rainfall.  For example, we find that the SPCZ experiences both active and quiescent periods during both El Niño and La Niña conditions.   We anticipate that our application of these tools will demonstrate their utility for evaluation of climate models and, hopefully, stimulate development of new approaches for multimodel evaluation. 

With respect to understanding CMIP5 model bias, we applied multimodel empirical mode reduction techniques, including empirical orthogonal function analysis, to output from these models for the tropical and South Pacific region.  Two significant regional modes of model spread were identified for the DJF rainfall climatology, one corresponding to the meridional width of the SPCZ-ITCZ complex and the other to tradeoff in intensity of rainfall along the SPCZ and ITCZ.  We related these patterns of rainfall spread to model spread in sea surface temperature and circulation, demonstrating the physical consistency between them.  An intended follow up to this work is to examine how patterns of model spread relate to the model representation of certain processes, such as entrainment of environmental air during deep convection, which are poorly constrained by observations.

Apart from this project’s scientific outcomes, it has also produced several notable broader impacts.  First and foremost, one PhD student was trained, funded, and completed his dissertation over the course of this project; a second PhD student has also begun a dissertation based on this project.  Three undergraduate students (all female and two African-American) participated in research directly or indirectly related to this project.  Moreover, the PI and colleagues organized a poster session on the SPCZ at the 2014 Fall American Geophysical Union meeting in San Francisco.  Finally, effort on this project has involved international collaboration, including one collaborator from the United Kingdom and one from Costa Rica.
